In l987, Thomas Cavalier-Smith suggested in Evolutionary Biology of the Fungi (Cambridge University Press, New York) that fungi are more closely related to animals than plants based on biochemical and ultrastructural criteria, such as complex biosynthetic pathways and the structure of cristae in mitochondria. They do not photosynthesize as do plants. Fungi are also distinguished by their ability to form spores and their lack of undulipodia, which are structures that provide cell motility in protists.
